case_name: Chairman of the Municipal Committee of Howrah v. the respondent company

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 240 of 1959 was filed by special leave in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 240 of 1959. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 15, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 135 of 1959.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court passed judgment and order dated July 15, 1959 in Criminal Revision No. 135 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated July 15, 1959, of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Revision No. 135 of 1959. C. Mazumdar, for the appellant. Sukumar Ghose, for the respondent No. 1. 1962. March 26.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on March 26, 1962 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. March 26. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Calcutta passed in revision against the order of the Additional Session, Judge, Howrah,

facts.text: Appellant is the Chairman of the Municipal Committee of Howrah, who is the complainant.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant before us is the Chairman of the Municipal Committee of Howrah who is the complainant and the respondent is a company with its premises at No. 1 Swarnamoyee Road, where it was carrying on the manufacture of bobbins, card pine, shuttles etc.

facts.text: Respondent is a company with premises at No. 1 Swarnamoyee Road, Howrah.

anchor.surface_text: and the respondent is a company with its premises at No. 1 Swarnamoyee Road, where it was carrying on the manufacture of bobbins, card pine, shuttles etc. They were also storing their wood and timer in those premises.

facts.text: Respondent was carrying on manufacture of bobbins, card pins, shuttles etc. at the premises.

anchor.surface_text: where it was carrying on the manufacture of bobbins, card pine, shuttles etc. They were also storing their wood and timer in those premises. The charge against the respondent was that it was using the premises within the municipality of Howrah without a license as required under s. 386 of the Act

facts.text: Respondent was storing wood and timber in the premises.

anchor.surface_text: They were also storing their wood and timer in those premises. The charge against the respondent was that it was using the premises within the municipality of Howrah without a license as required under s. 386 of the Act and was therefore guilty under s. 488 of the Act.

facts.text: Respondent used premises without license under s. 386 of the Calcutta Municipal Act as extended to Howrah Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: The charge against the respondent was that it was using the premises within the municipality of Howrah without a license as required under s. 386 of the Act and was therefore guilty under s. 488 of the Act. The defence of the respondent was that the premises had been licensed as a warehouse under the West Bengal Fire Services Act, 1950

facts.text: Respondent was convicted under s. 488 read with s. 386(1)(b) of the Calcutta Municipal Act 1923 as extended to Howrah.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the respondent was that the premises had been licensed as a warehouse under the West Bengal Fire Services Act, 1950  Act 18 of 1950  and consequently because of s. 38 of that Act, s. 386 of the Act stood repealed and the respondent was no longer required to take out another license under, s. 386 of the Act.

facts.text: Premises licensed as warehouse under West Bengal Fire Services Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the respondent was that the premises had been licensed as a warehouse under the West Bengal Fire Services Act, 1950  Act 18 of 1950  and consequently because of s. 38 of that Act, s. 386 of the Act stood repealed and the respondent was no longer required to take out another license under, s. 386 of the Act.

facts.text: Magistrate convicted respondent and sentenced to fine of Rs. 250.

anchor.surface_text: He convicted the respondent under s. 488 and sentenced him to a fine of Rs. 250. In appeal the learned Additional Sessions Judge held that s. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act does no repeal all the three clauses of s. 386 of the Act but partially repeals a. 386 3  which deals with the levy of fees

facts.text: Magistrate found respondent running factory with workshops fitted with electric power for manufacture of bobbins, card pins, shuttles.

anchor.surface_text: He found that the respondent was running a factory with workshops fitted with electric power in the premises for the manufacture of bobbins, card pins, shuttles etc. He convicted the respondent under s. 488 and sentenced him to a fine of Rs. 250.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge, Howrah modified conviction to fine of Rs. 10.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the learned Additional Sessions Judge held that s. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act does number repeal all the three clauses of s. 386 of the Act but partially repeals a. 386 3  which deals with the levy of fees and therefore a license under s. 386 1  will still have to be taken but as the premises had al. ready been licensed as a warehouse the respondent company could number be required to pay any fees under a. 386 3  of the Act.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court dismissed revision petition against Sessions Judge's order.

anchor.surface_text: The revision was therefore dismissed, and the rule was discharged. Against that order the appellant has come in appeal by special leave. The main argument raised by the appellant was that s. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act could no affect the operation of s. 386 of the Calcutta Municipal Act as it was extended to the Howrah Municipality.

facts.text: Calcutta Municipal Act III of 1923 extended to Howrah Municipality by Gazette Notification No. 260M dated January 18, 1932.

anchor.surface_text: By a Gazette Notification NO. 260M of January 18, 1932 practically the whole of the Act, excepting the provisions which are number necessary, was extended to the Municipality of Howrah. The language extending the Act was as follows- Howrah.-No. 260M.-18th January 1932-In exercise of the power conferred by sub-section  2  of section 541 of the Calcutta Municipal Act, 1923  Bengal Act III of 19-3 . the Government of Bengal

facts.text: Extension modified s.386 by substituting 'Commissioners' for 'Corporation of Calcutta'.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this extension s. 386 was extended to the Municipality of Howrah with this modification that in place of the word Corporation of Calcutta the word Commissioners was substituted. In 1951 the Calcutta Municipal Act 1951 being West Bengal Act 33 of 1951 was enacted thus replacing Act 3 of 1923 which was therefore repealed.

facts.text: Calcutta Municipal Act 1951 (West Bengal Act 33 of 1951) enacted, repealing 1923 Act, but 1923 provisions continue for Howrah until new extension.

anchor.surface_text: In 1951 the Calcutta Municipal Act 1951 being West Bengal Act 33 of 1951 was enacted thus replacing Act 3 of 1923 which was therefore repealed. In the new Act corresponding provision to ss. 540, 541 and 542 are ss. 589, 590 and 591. Section 614 of the new Act provides that the provisions of Act III of 1923 as extended to the Municipality of Howrah shall continue to be in force until the provisions of the new Act are extended to that Municipality under the new Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that s.38 of West Bengal Fire Services Act does not repeal s.386 as modified for Howrah Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion therefore the contention of the appellant is well founded and s. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act does number repeal s. 386 as modified and as applicable to the Municipality of Howrah. From the point of view of the respondent the result may be unfortunate

facts.text: Respondent's defence that s.38 of Fire Services Act repealed requirement for license under s.386.

anchor.surface_text: and consequently because of s. 38 of that Act, s. 386 of the Act stood repealed and the respondent was number required to take out another license under, s. 386 of the Act. The Magistrate, before whom the case was tried, was of the opinion that the effect of a. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act was that the power of the Municipality to require a license under a. 386 of the Act for user as a warehouse had been taken away

facts.text: High Court held s.38 applicable to Howrah Municipality.

anchor.surface_text: But the High Court was of the opinion that a. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act is applicable to the Howrah Municipality and therefore repelled this last argument. The revision was therefore dismissed, and the rule was discharged.

facts.text: Appellant argued s.38 does not apply to Howrah as governed by extended Calcutta Municipal Act, not Bengal Municipal Act.

anchor.surface_text: A further argument was also raised for the appellant in the High Court and that was that a. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act did number apply to the Howrah Municipality at all because the Howrah Municipality is governed neither by the Calcutta Municipal Act number by the Bengal Municipal Act but by the Calcutta Municipal Act as extended to Howrah i. e. as modified

facts.text: West Bengal Fire Services Act, 1950 (Act 18 of 1950) enacted.

anchor.surface_text: under the West Bengal Fire Services Act, 1950  Act 18 of 1950  and consequently because of s. 38 of that Act, s. 386 of the Act stood repealed and the respondent was number required to take out another license under, s. 386 of the Act.

facts.text: Calcutta Municipal Act III of 1923 applicable to Howrah via extension under ss.540,541.

anchor.surface_text: To test the correctness of this argument it is necessary to refer to the provisions by which the Act was extended to the Municipality of Howrah. Under so. 540 and 541 of the Calcutta Municipal Act the Provincial Government was empowered to extend all or any of the provision of that Act to the Municipality of Howrah.

anchor.surface_text: The defence of the respondent was that the premises had been licensed as a warehouse under the West Bengal Fire Services Act, 1950 Act 18 of 1950 and consequently because of s. 38 of that Act, s. 386 of the Act stood repealed and the respondent was number required to take out another license under, s. 386 of the Act. The Magistrate,

anchor.surface_text: the effect of a. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act was that the power of the Municipality to require a license under a. 386 of the Act for user as a warehouse had been taken away and therefore in respect of the rest of the premises used as a factory or for other purposes the applicability of s. 386 remains unimpaired. He found that the respondent was running a factory

issues.text: Whether s. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act applies to or repeals s. 386 of the Calcutta Municipal Act as modified and extended to the Howrah Municipality

anchor.surface_text: A further argument was also raised for the appellant in the High Court and that was that s. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act did number apply to the Howrah Municipality at all because the Howrah Municipality is governed neither by the Calcutta Municipal Act number by the Bengal Municipal Act but by the Calcutta Municipal Act as extended to Howrah i. e. as modified in accordance with the powers companyferred on the Government by s. 541 2  of the Calcutta Municipal Act. But the High Court was of the opinion that a. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act is applicable to the Howrah Municipality and therefore repelled this last argument. The revision was therefore dismissed, and the rule was discharged. Against that order the appellant has companye in appeal by special leave. arguments.court_reasoning: Howrah's s.386 modified by substituting 'Commissioners' for 'Corporation'; functions as distinct provision

arguments.claim: s.38 does not repeal modified s.386 applicable to Howrah as it is a different provision due to textual modification ('Commissioners' instead of 'Corporation'); analogous to incorporation by reference not affected by amendments

anchor.surface_text: Section 38 provides that section repeals s. 386 of the Act III of 1925 to the extent therein mentioned. It also repeals s. 370 of the Bengal Municipal Act as it applies to the Commissioners of Municipalities in Bengal. It does number apply to s. 386 as modified and is inapplicable to the Municipality of Howrah because in s. 386 as applicable to the Corporation of Calcutta the word used is ,Corporation and number Commissioners

arguments.claim: Extension under ss.540-542 makes s.386 as modified applicable to Howrah, superseding Bengal Municipal Act; 1951 Act continues it via s.614

anchor.surface_text: To test the correctness of this argument it is necessary to refer to the provisions by which the Act was extended to the Municipality of Howrah. Under so. 540 and 541 of the Calcutta Municipal Act the Provincial Government was empowered to extend all or any of the provision of that Act to the Municipality of Howrah.

arguments.claim: Precedent of Secretary of State v. Hindusthan Insurance supports that incorporated provisions not affected by later amendments to original Act

anchor.surface_text: In a somewhat similar case a similar view was taken by the Privy Council. See Secretary of State for India v. Hindusthan Co-operative lnsurance Society  1 . In that case certain provisions of the Land Acquisition Act were incorporated by reference Into the Calcutta Improvement Act 1911.

holdings.text: s. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act does not repeal s. 386 as modified and as applicable to the Municipality of Howrah

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion therefore the contention of the appellant is well founded and s. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act does not repeal s. 386 as modified and as applicable to the Municipality of Howrah. From the point of view of the respondent the result may be unfortunate

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.38 targets unmodified s.386 of Calcutta Municipal Act referring to 'Corporation of Calcutta' and s.370 of Bengal Municipal Act; Howrah's version modified by substituting 'Commissioners'; functions as distinct provision like incorporation by reference

holdings.text: Section 38 does not apply to s. 386 as modified and is inapplicable to the Municipality of Howrah because in s. 386 as applicable to the Corporation of Calcutta the word used is 'Corporation' and not 'Commissioners'

anchor.surface_text: Section 38 provides that section repeals s. 386 of the Act III of 1923 to the extent therein mentioned. It also repeals s. 370 of the Bengal Municipal Act as it applies to the Commissioners of Municipalities in Bengal. It does not apply to s. 386 as modified and is inapplicable to the Municipality of Howrah because in s. 386 as applicable to the Corporation of Calcutta the word used is ,Corporation and not Commissioners

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual difference in key terms ('Corporation' vs 'Commissioners') due to extension under s.541(2); repeal specific to unmodified provisions

holdings.text: Thus modified it is not s.386 of the Calcutta Municipal Act but a different section. Therefore what s.38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act repeals is s. 386 of the Calcutta Municipal Act and not s. 386 of that as modified and applied to the Municipality of Howrah

anchor.surface_text: Although s. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act extends to the whole of Bengal and to the extent there set out it repeals s. 386 of the Calcutta Municipal Act which applies to the Corporation of Calcutta and s. 370 which applies to the other Municipalities of Bengal yet it does not affect the operation of s. 386 of the former Act as modified and extended to the Municipality of Howrah by the notification which has been set out above. The reason for that is that the language of s. 386 has been modified to make it appropriate in its application to the Municipality of Howrah and for that purpose in place of the word Corporation the word Commissioners has been substituted. Thus modified it is not s.386 of the Calcutta Municipal Act but a different section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Modification via extension notification creates independent provision unaffected by targeted repeal; supported by Privy Council precedent on incorporation by reference

precedents.citation: Secretary of State for India v. Hindusthan Co-operative lnsurance Society 1

anchor.surface_text: See Secretary of State for India v. Hindusthan Co-operative lnsurance Society 1 . In that case certain provisions of the Land Acquisition Act were incorporated by reference Into the Calcutta Improvement Act 1911. By an amendment of 1921 the right of appeal to the Privy Council from the decision of the High Court was provided in matters failing under the Land Acquisition Act.

precedents.case_name: Secretary of State for India v. Hindusthan Co-operative Insurance Society
precedents.cited_proposition: Provisions of an existing Act incorporated by reference into a subsequent Act are not affected by subsequent amendments to the original Act unless expressly made applicable
precedents.cited_holding: the right of appeal so given was not applicable to the award of a tribunal under the Calcutta Improvement Act assessing compensation in respect of land acquired under the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act

anchor.surface_text: quoted with 1 approval the observations of Lord Westbury in Ex parts St. Sepulchres 1 and observed It seems to be numberless logical to hold that where certain provisions from an existing Act have been incorporated into a subsequent Act, numberaddition to the former Act, which is number expressly made applicable to the subsequent Act, can be deemed to be incorporated in it, at all events if it is possible for the subsequent Act to function effectually without the addition.

precedents.cited_proposition: where certain provisions from an existing Act have been incorporated into a subsequent Act, no addition to the former Act, which is not expressly made applicable to the subsequent Act, can be deemed to be incorporated in it
precedents.cited_holding: It seems to be no less logical to hold that where certain provisions from an existing Act have been incorporated into a subsequent Act, no addition to the former Act, which is not expressly made applicable to the subsequent Act, can be deemed to be incorporated in it, at all events if it is possible for the subsequent Act to function effectually without the addition

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion therefore the contention of the appellant is well founded and s. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act does number repeal s. 386 as modified and as applicable to the Municipality of Howrah.

outcome.relief_summary: Appellant's contention upheld that s. 38 of West Bengal Fire Services Act does not repeal s. 386 of Calcutta Municipal Act as modified and extended to Howrah Municipality

anchor.surface_text: Section 38 provides that section repeals s. 386 of the Act III of 1923 to the extent therein mentioned. It also repeals s. 370 of the Bengal Municipal Act as it applies to the Commissioners of Municipalities in Bengal. It does not apply to s. 386 as modified and is inapplicable to the Municipality of Howrah because in s. 386 as applicable to the Corporation of Calcutta the word used is ,Corporation and not Commissioners

In our opinion therefore the contention of the appellant is well founded and s. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act does number repeal s. 386 as modified and as applicable to the Municipality of Howrah.

anchor.surface_text: her anomalous but that is what the effect of the modification of the language is. In our opinion therefore the companytention of the appellant is well

edges.explanation: Holding h3 states that the modified s.386 is a different section and s.38 repeals only s.386 of the Calcutta Municipal Act, directly addressing the issue of applicability or repeal of the modified version.

anchor.surface_text: Although s. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act extends to the whole of Bengal and to the extent there set out it repeals s. 386 of the Calcutta Municipal Act which applies to the Corporation of Calcutta and s. 370 which applies to the other Municipalities of Bengal yet it does not affect the operation of s. 386 of the former Act as modified and extended to the Municipality of Howrah by the notification which has been set out above. The reason for that is that the language of s. 386 has been modified to make it appropriate in its application to the Municipality of Howrah and for that purpose in place of the word Corporation the word Commissioners has been substituted. Thus modified it is not s.386 of the Calcutta Municipal Act but a different section.

In our opinion therefore the contention of the appellant is well founded and s. 38 of the West Bengal Fire Services Act does number repeal s. 386 as modified and as applicable to the Municipality of Howrah.
